s0:
The starting point is the creation of an App within the developer portal at https://dev.freeagent.com/login. Once the App has been created, click on it within the portal to edit it, and two keys should become visible: 'OAuth identifier' and 'OAuth secret'. Rather confusingly, FreeAgent guidance then refers to these as the ClientID and the Client Secret tokens. So from here on, these two strings are referred to as the Client ID and either the Client Secret or just the Secret Token.

Both are strings of text looking something like this 'MyeuHkExlB8nJrdx6mTDyA'. Copy both keys and paste them into a Word document or a text editor as they are needed in the next step. You can now close the FreeAgent Developer page.

Click the 'Open Google setup' button. A new web page will open and you will be greeted by the following:

Click on the 'ok thats fine' button and you will have a google page open within which the next steps are carried out. If you have a google page open then click on the 'show steps' button back up at the top to see the next set of instructions.

s1:
The web page that is open is provided by google for companies that want to set up interface connectors called 'apis' that allow access to their data.

To the right at 1. you will see two boxes for the two keys copied from the previous step. Copy and paste each key into its respective box. There is no 'submit' button to press. Over to the left at 2. click on the little arrow to the left of 'step 1' which will reveal the following.

At 3. you need to enter some text. A few characters will do, they play no role within this exercise however Google needs the box populated. Then click on 'authorise apis' at step 4. A new window will open which is a FreeAgent login form. Click on the 'show steps' button back at the top to see the next set of instructions.

s2:
This is the step that ensures that no unauthorised use of apis to access data can take place. Enter your FreeAgent user name (email address) and password within the form and click 'Approve App'.

You will then be taken back to the earlier google page which will now be populated with an 'Authorisation Code'. Click on the 'show steps' button to see the next set of instructions.

s3:
Click on the 'Exchange Authorisation Code for Tokens' button at 5. and you will see the two boxes below, for the Access Token and Refresh Token, populate.

Click on the 'show steps' button for the last part of the process.

s4:
Copy and paste the two tokens that appear into a word document or text editor as they will be needed for the final step.

These two keys permit on-going access to the FreeAgent data. The Access Token typically lasts 7 days. However the Refresh Token never expires and can be used to obtain another Access Token at any time, even after the Access Token has expired.

You can employ the refresh token within this window, however the final step involves pasting the 4 keys that you should have (Client ID, Client Secret, Access Token, Refresh Token) into their respective boxes above in order that you shouldn't have to use the refresh token. Whenever data is requested from the FreeAgent database, this interface controller will detect if the Access Token has expired and it will automatically use the Refresh Token to request another. You shouldn't be aware that this process has taken place. Any problems however and the steps outlined in this guide can be followed whenever needed.

NOW, PLEASE COPY AND PASTE THE CLIENT ID, AND THE CLIENT SECRET, ACCESS TOKEN AND REFRESH TOKENS INTO THEIR RESPECTIVE BOXES ABOVE AND CLICK 'SUBMIT'.
